thread.title: World Superbikes: Jonathan Rea targets record third title triumph
thread.title_full: World Superbikes: Jonathan Rea targets record third title triumph

title: World Superbikes: Jonathan Rea targets record third title triumph
text:
Read more about sharing. Jonathan Rea clinched his second world title in Qatar in October Jonathan Rea is eyeing a record third successive World Superbike crown as he begins a new season on his Kawasaki at Phillip Island, Australia this weekend. 
The Northern Irishman is one of four riders to clinch back-to-back Superbike titles but is aiming to become the first to clinch three in a row. 
"I believe in our ability as a team, as a manufacturer and in myself as an individual," said the 30-year-old. 
"I'm starting from zero and thinking of this as a completely new challenge." Media playback is not supported on this device Jonathan Rea will again be in Kawasaki colours for the 2017 season 
Rea still lies two titles behind Carl Fogarty's record of four championship successes but will start this season as favourite after recording a phenomenal 46 podiums from his 52 races to date with Kawasaki. 
The Isle of Man-based rider has already laid down a marker by topping this week's timesheets in the final pre-season outing at Phillip Island. 
"I have to be clever, stay healthy and injury-free, and put a good season together," said Rea. 
"I'm putting the thought of three championships to the back of my mind and just focusing on the first race. I have the right people behind me to help me with the job," he added. Media playback is not supported on this device Carl Fogarty on Jonathan Rea 
The Ulsterman's main rival this season is expected to be Ducati-mounted Chaz Davies, given the strong manner in which the Welshman finished last season. 
Rea's Kawasaki team-mate Tom Sykes and Italian Marco Melandri, another Ducati rider, will also hope to be in the mix. 
Toomebridge rider Eugene Laverty is back in the series after two campaigns in the MotoGP paddock but is struggling to find a good set-up with his Milwaukee Aprilia. 
Laverty is a twice former race winner at Phillip Island but faces an uphill struggle to secure a high leaderboard finish. 
The first race of the new season will take place at 04:00 GMT on Saturday, with the second at the same time on Sunday. Share this page
